topic.title: Buckets, Memory, and Storage
topic.shortdesc: Couchbase Server saves data-items in Buckets.

section.title: Creating, Maintaining, and Accessing Data
section.p: Couchbase Server keeps data-items in Buckets. Before a data-item can be saved by an application or user, a bucket must exist within which the data-item can be saved. Buckets can be created by means of the Couchbase Web Console, the REST API, or the CLI. Each bucket is assigned a name at its creation: this name is referenced by the application or user wishing to save or access data-items within it.

The buckets most frequently used are Couchbase and Ephemeral buckets. Couchbase buckets exist in both memory and on disk; Ephemeral exist only in memory. Buckets can be configured to maintain data in compressed format, so as to maximize resource-effectiveness. Individual documents within a bucket can be assigned a Time To Live, to ensure that they expire after a specified time-period, thus rendering their data permanently inaccessible.

Couchbase Server manages memory to ensure high performance and scalability: memory quotas are established, and data not recently used can be ejected, to make way for data more frequently requested. Multithreaded readers and writers provide simultaneous read and write operations for data on disk, ensuring high I/O throughput.
The pages in this section describe buckets, memory, storage, and all associated matters in detail.
